lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: That which hath made them drunk hath made me bold; What hath quench'd them hath given me fire. Hark! Peace! It was the owl that shriek'd, the fatal bellman, Which gives the stern'st good-night. He is about it: The doors are open; and the surfeited grooms Do mock their charge with snores: I have drugg'd their possets, That death and nature do contend about them, Whether they live or die.

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: Alack, I am afraid they have awaked, And 'tis not done. The attempt and not the deed Confounds us. Hark! I laid their daggers ready; He could not miss 'em. Had he not resembled My father as he slept, I had done't. My husband!

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: I have done the deed. Didst thou not hear a noise?

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: I heard the owl scream and the crickets cry. Did not you speak?

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: Hark! Who lies i' the second chamber?

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: A foolish thought, to say a sorry sight.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: There's one did laugh in's sleep, and one cried 'Murder!' That they did wake each other: I stood and heard them: But they did say their prayers, and address'd them Again to sleep.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: One cried 'God bless us!' and 'Amen' the other; As they had seen me with these hangman's hands. Listening their fear, I could not say 'Amen,' When they did say 'God bless us!'

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: But wherefore could not I pronounce 'Amen'? I had most need of blessing, and 'Amen' Stuck in my throat.

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: These deeds must not be thought After these ways; so, it will make us mad.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: Methought I heard a voice cry 'Sleep no more! Macbeth does murder sleep', the innocent sleep, Sleep that knits up the ravell'd sleeve of care, The death of each day's life, sore labour's bath, Balm of hurt minds, great nature's second course, Chief nourisher in life's feast,--

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: Still it cried 'Sleep no more!' to all the house: 'Glamis hath murder'd sleep, and therefore Cawdor Shall sleep no more; Macbeth shall sleep no more.'

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: Who was it that thus cried? Why, worthy thane, You do unbend your noble strength, to think So brainsickly of things. Go get some water, And wash this filthy witness from your hand. Why did you bring these daggers from the place? They must lie there: go carry them; and smear The sleepy grooms with blood.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: I'll go no more: I am afraid to think what I have done; Look on't again I dare not.

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: Infirm of purpose! Give me the daggers: the sleeping and the dead Are but as pictures: 'tis the eye of childhood That fears a painted devil. If he do bleed, I'll gild the faces of the grooms withal; For it must seem their guilt.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: Whence is that knocking? How is't with me, when every noise appals me? What hands are here? ha! they pluck out mine eyes. Will all great Neptune's ocean wash this blood Clean from my hand? No, this my hand will rather The multitudinous seas in incarnadine, Making the green one red.

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: My hands are of your colour; but I shame To wear a heart so white. I hear a knocking At the south entry: retire we to our chamber; A little water clears us of this deed: How easy is it, then! Your constancy Hath left you unattended. Hark! more knocking. Get on your nightgown, lest occasion call us, And show us to be watchers. Be not lost So poorly in your thoughts.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: To know my deed, 'twere best not know myself. Wake Duncan with thy knocking! I would thou couldst!
